params.text:
Reading

Understand a short email

Language in Action

• Identify the nature and purpose of an email
  • Learn tips to understand better
  • Recognize interrogative, negative and affirmative sentences
Reading: Introduction

Emails help us share information, ask questions, and get things done. In this module, we'll become email ninjas and learn some key skills to understand them better:

Here's what you'll learn:

1. Understanding the Email Goal: Learn how to identify the main purpose of the email - is it asking something, sharing information, or requesting something?

  2. Email Power Tips: Discover tricks to grasp the email content quickly and easily.

  3. Sentence Savvy: Learn to recognize different types of sentences in emails, like questions, "no" statements, and "yes" statements.
Identify The Nature And Purpose Of An Email: Key Points
Emails are like letters at work. They tell us things. Let's learn how to understand what they want!
Look at the first part:
Check the last part:
• The beginning of the email often tells us what it's about.
Look for special words:
• The end of the email can also be important.
• Some words like "please" or "question" can help too.
Identify The Nature And Purpose Of An Email - Sentences

params.textField:
"See you at the meeting." This email is *about* a meeting.
"Please send me the report." This email is *asking* for something.
"Hi John, Can you help me?" This email *wants* John to help.

metadata.title: Identify The Nature And Purpose Of An Email - Drag the words

params.text: Identify The Nature And Purpose Of An Email - Quiz
Read each question carefully and choose the BEST way to understand an email in English.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: You get an email that says "The meeting is at 2 PM." What is the email about?
Question 2 of 3: You receive an email that starts with "Hi Alex, Can you help me?" What does the email want?
answers:
To ask for help.

To share information.

To say goodbye.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: An email says "Please send me the report." What does the email want?
answers:
To ask for a report.

To share a report.

To say thank you.

metadata.title: Identify The Nature And Purpose Of An Email - Quiz

params.text: Learn Tips To Understand Emails Better: Key Points

Emails are like letters at work.

Here are some tips to crack the code:
Read the Subject Line:
Check the First Sentence:

• This tells you what the email is about.
    Example: An email with "Meeting Tomorrow" in the subject line is about a meeting
Look for Important Words:

• The first sentence often explains why the email was sent.
    Example: "Hi John, Can you send me the report?" This email wants the report

• Words like "please" or "meeting" can be clues.
    Example: "Please bring your laptop to the meeting." This email is asking you to do something

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: You get an email with the subject "Meeting Cancelled." What can you guess?
answers:
The meeting will not happen.

There will be a new meeting.

You need to bring food to the meeting.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: An email says "Hi Alex, Please send me the file." What does the email want?
answers:
To give Alex a file.

To ask Alex for a file.

To thank Alex for a file.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: You get an email that starts with "The new product launch is on Friday."
What is the email about?
answers:
Sharing information about the product.

A question about the product.

Asking for help with the product.

metadata.title: Learn Tips To Understand Emails Better - Quiz

params.text: Learn Tips To Understand Emails Better - Listening & Quiz
Please listen to the conversation between Abigail and Bryan, and answer the questions below:
Bryan:
Micah:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Micah: Emails are hard! I don't always understand them.

Bryan: Me too! I look at the first part. It helps.

Micah: Yes, and the last part is good too. Sometimes, there are special words like "please" or "meeting."

Bryan: I know! Those help a lot. We can learn together.

params.text: Recognise Interrogative, Negative, And Affirmative Sentences

Emails use different kinds of sentences to tell us things.
Let's learn to spot them!
Asking Questions (Interrogative Sentences)
Saying "No" (Negative Sentences)

•  Start with "who," "what," "where," "when," "why," or "how."
    Example: "Where is the meeting?"
  • Use a question mark at the end.
    Example: "Can you help me?"
Saying "Yes" (Affirmative Sentences)

• Use words like "not," "don't," "can't," or "isn't."
    Example: "I don't have the report."
    Example: "She isn't coming to the meeting."

• Use words like "is," "are," "can," or "will."
    Example: "I can help you."
    Example: "The meeting is at 2 PM."
Recognise Interrogative, Negative, And Affirmative Sentences - Quiz
Read each question carefully and choose the BEST answer:

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Which sentence is asking a question?
answers:
Can you send it to me?

I have the report.

The report is ready.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Which sentence is saying "no"?
answers:
I cannot come.

I will be there.

The meeting is at 3 PM.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Which sentence is saying "yes"?
answers:
I can help you.

Do you have the time?

She is not coming.

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Test your instruction-following skills! Choose the BEST answer for each question to show what you learned in this module.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: You get an email that says "The meeting is at 2 PM." What is the email about?
Question 2 of 3: An email starts with "Hi Alex, Can you help me?" What does the email want?
answers:
To ask for help.

To share information.

To say goodbye.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What is the best way to understand an email quickly?
answers:
Look at the first sentence and the subject line.

Read every word slowly.

Ignore the email.
